page.title: 10The Severn Bore.
page.content: The Severn Bore is a big tidal wave. As it moves past, smaller waves can be seen moving behind. The tide follows it up the river towards Gloucester. The current of the river can be seen to reverse completely. The road nearby can be submerged within 45 minutes. This phenomenon occurs as a result of the combination of tides and the shape of the estuary. There are about 200 Bores a year. The biggest tides (up to 15m at Sharpness) are in March and September at the equinoxes. These are the best times for Bore watching. What of the future? If proposals for a Severn barrage come about, the spectacle of the bore will be a thing of the past. Local people who speak of "their" Bore with pride will not want this to happen, and tourists will be deprived of yet another landmark, or, in this instance - tidemark.
